name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @CousinAmygdala Another one: @petrzzz and @TonyZador taught rodents to judge whether a time-varying  "cloud of tones" was overall high or low. Stimulation of auditory neurons the project to the posterior striatium biased the psychometric function (pSTR is topographic)  https://t.co/vyiz54fEYS

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @CousinAmygdala There are some differences for sure: NHPs reported with a saccade, which was helpful, I was stimulating in an area with topography, which leads to a bias ‚àÜ instead of sensitivity ‚àÜ, & NHPs had 5 yrs+ experience w/ the task so 0% lapse rate. But complexity was pretty similar.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @CousinAmygdala The experimental paradigm was similar in complexity to one I used to electrically stimulate MT in NHPs: multiple stimulus strengths (so one can generate a PMF), flutuating stimuli, small percentage of opto stim trials. In rodent, we repeated in control animal not expressing ChR2.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @CousinAmygdala Dunno. We trained rodents to judge whether visual repetition rate was hi/lo relative to an abstract category boundary. Opto stim reduced sensitivity. B/c stim was stochastic & time varying, we then computed psychophysical kernals for laser on vs. off to understand timecourse.  https://t.co/jb2r4qdCpM

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 3/4 Fauci then described the "breathtaking success" of covid19 vaccines, but distinguished "efficacy": how well the vaccine works in clinical trials vs. "effectiveness": how well a vblunts disease in the community. They are not the same & reluntance to take the vaccine is reality

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 2/4 Vaccine work at @NIH extended to RSV & later sars-& mers-cov. LOTS was learned about rational vaccine design using pre-fusion configuration of proteins. The same idea is repurposed in almost all the covid-19 vaccines: perform mutations to get a stable pre-fusion spike protein

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 1/4 The Advisory Committee to the @NIHDirector got updated by Dr. Fauci. He started by highlighting some history of vaccine efforts @NIH. name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @CellTypist @SaraASolla @jpillowtime Sometimes we find that what we thought was a neural signature of our favorite computation actually reflects several different sorts of computations which, by coincidence, add up to look like something simple when they are not.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @CellTypist @SaraASolla @jpillowtime So in the end, we often end up taking a different approach. When we don't find an obvious signature of the computation were hoping for, we instead step back and say, "Okay, so what IS here in the data". And that's when the interesting stuff usually pops up.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @CellTypist @SaraASolla @jpillowtime So although we have behavioral evidence for these computations, the predicted neural computations were not obvious. Similar thing happened w/ our search for neural basis of optimal cue combination. Again, behavior is beautiful and clear, neurons... not so much.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @CellTypist @SaraASolla @jpillowtime E.g. we aimed to expose decision-specific activity by comparing experts vs. novice brains. The difference, we reasoned, would reflect accum of evidence, bayesian integration etc. But expert/novice brains were v. similar b/c activity in both was dominated by uninstructed movements

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @dileeplearning @SaraASolla @jpillowtime I am working on a review now that makes this point.

tweet: @SaraASolla @jpillowtime Great point @SaraASolla. We experimentalists like & want to find the algorithms. And we go looking for them in the neural activity we measure. And then we look at the data and we're like.... what????? And the data just calls for a new approach.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @melisyilmaz @RetractionWatch 2/2 I hope we can agree that if flaws in the NC paper exceed the existing threshold for paper retraction, then, like any other paper, it should be retracted. The fact that some bad papers from your J. Club weren't retracted is not evidence that the NC paper should be given a pass

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @melisyilmaz 1/2 Trying to find common ground here: I agree that retraction is a serious action, not to be taken lightly. Indeed, having spent some time on the @RetractionWatch database today, I would like to know more about which flaws with data/results led to retraction & which did not.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @bjmarlin Thanks for posting this important story üò¢

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @melisyilmaz @emekdemir @pollyp1 @NatureComms The retractionwatch database contrains **24,452**retracted papers. Retraction occurs for a variety of reasons, and "concerns/issues about data/results" are high on the list. @RetractionWatch.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @melisyilmaz @emekdemir @pollyp1 @NatureComms Agree. The grounds are:  1 Flaws in exp design, raised by reviewers, were ignored 2 Results depend on how mentorship is defined; the method was flawed  3 Confounds (e.g. citation gender gap) were ignored  4 Inferences from data were used to propose policies that are not justified

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @melisyilmaz @emekdemir @pollyp1 @NatureComms Is your argument that there are other flawed papers that are not retracted and therefore this one should likewise not be retracted? Note that papers are retracted all the time due to flaws. Here is a whole database of retracted papers:  https://t.co/lPSq7yb0Wr

tweet: @lucylai_  spoke at @NAISys about the division of learning labor for motor learning. She used the context of key for piano scales as an example. She leaves us w/ some cool questions: How do biological agents learn relevant state spaces? How do we teach robots to discover that

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: At #NAISys, @SussilloDavid offers insight into the problem of contextual processing via undersatnding Yelp reviews! Take home: there are 2 ways to handle context: changes in recurrent dynamics or changes in the matrix that defines how inputs change the system (i/p Jacobian).

tweet: Great talk from @chelseabfinn at #NAISys about how to provide grasping robots w/ data that is more like what biological networks experience. Take home: use of "interesting" training data, such as a human demonstrater, can be used to direct future data collection & speed things up

tweet: @Tessadunlop Also, here is a new article about flu vs. COVID. Summary: Hospitalized patients w/ COVID had a more than 5X higher risk for in-hospital death and increased risk for 17 respiratory + nonrespiratory complications vs hospitalized patients with flu.  https://t.co/2XzOASdQv4

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @Tessadunlop @Cinetti Also remember that the "death rate" is strongly dependent on the population incidence. Vaccines keep flu incidence low, so sick patients can get hospital care. With COVID, the lack of a vaccine can mean that hospitals can get overrun. This increases the death rate. #StayHome

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @Tessadunlop @JulieOwenMoylan Yep, flu is dangerous. In the US, it kills ~30K people/yr. So far in the US, COVID has killed 230K people. Almost an 8-fold difference and it is only October. My tip: protect yourself from both as best you can.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @JulieOwenMoylan @Tessadunlop Agree. The existence of the flu vaccine is a game changer; even if only ~45% of adults get the flu vaccine, this greatly reduces the number of people who get it, slowing the spread. Until we can do this for COVID, we need more severe public health measures than we would normally.

tweet: @StevenDakin @MatteoCarandini @IntlBrainLab You could detect a bias, but to your point, it's magnitude would be difficult to discern. Agree. Still, at least the presence of a bias is visible to a viewer, this is a downside of the folded PMF.

tweet: @MatteoCarandini @StevenDakin @IntlBrainLab For example:  https://t.co/8tw3VNARQM

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @MatteoCarandini @StevenDakin @IntlBrainLab It is always a challenge to handle 0 stimulus strength on the abscissa. An alternative is to "fold" the PMF and indicate a break in the abscissa right before 0, but this means that left & right choices are pooled, obscuring bias.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @kaymtye This is unlike other MS in which, e.g., a high rate visual stim & a low rate auditory stim give rise to the same firing rate (black arrow). If you observe that firing rate in a single neuron, you can't know which of those stimulus conditions caused it. 2/2  https://t.co/IRZyqQfPMY

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @kaymtye True, true. I would evaluate the cell's possible MS by doing a decoding analysis. If we could decode both light & sound intensity with roughly equal accuracy from a single neuron, then I say NO to MS. 1/2

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @AdamHantman @kaymtye Most do. It is the nonlinear mixed selectivity that is especially interesting and can allow for a nice linear decode (as in Rigotti). The mixed selectivity we saw in PPC, by contrast, was mostly linear.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @kaymtye Yes on Cell 1, cell 2 is a little dubious; I would need to know more. For instance, are we sure that the modulation is really due to salience? Plus, if volume and brightness scaled the firing rate with a steeper slope for one that the other, I would call that MS.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @cian_neuro @lukesjulson @MatteoCarandini @TonyZador Phototransduction is slow which causes a reliable delay. The problem w/ slow monitors is that the apparent motion drives a mismatch between target speed and eye speed. At really slow rates, motion looks jumpy; at intermediate rates, it looks ok but you track it badly.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @TonyZador Pls buy your son a faster monitor. Speed estimates are warped at long ‚àÜt (probably due to the way the population of MT neurons is read out). So a gamer with a slow monitor would mis-estimate the speed and could make errors. My paper on this subject:   https://t.co/uOGm7yV2gN

tweet: @JAlGallego @neuroecology I have used @toodledo since I started my lab 9 yrs ago & I love it! name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @neuroecology Use a task manager. There are lots of good ones. The key thing is that you can write down tasks, group them in a few different ways, and assign them priorities. Don't rely on your memory for anything. Busy brains forget stuff.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @nytimes 3/3  Finally, they had a thoughtful experimental design including ‚Äútuned" & ‚Äúrandom‚Äù populations (plus NEW tuned & random populations to test for generalization, fig 4i).   https://t.co/1MIwWvcgoW

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @nytimes 2/3 But perturbations still allow us to answer key questions. Like, how does a neural population influence downstream areas & behavior? Key advances in current paper include multiSLM to stimulate neurons based on function, and a red-shifted opsin allowing simultaneous 2p.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 1/3 Cool to see K. Diesseroth's latest paper highlighted in @nytimes, but they didn't exactly nail my point of view. W/ perturbations, we can‚Äôt know animals' inner experiences b/c we don‚Äôt get verbal reports. This is true in the Diesseroth work & mine too!  https://t.co/PsaaajPju9

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @alfairhall @edyong209 2/2 Part of my skepticism is that even a simulation with as many neurons as the brain differs from the brain in a fundamental way: it doesn't have a body to move around. Our brains evolved to move our bodies, so a disembodied brain is hard to make sense of.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 1/2 I share HBP's vision that theoretical neuro will play a key role in our understanding of the brain. But I am skeptical that large-scale simulations are the way to go. @alfairhall & I enjoyed discussing this w/ @edyong209.   https://t.co/uhigo6UHmB

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @SaraASolla @KnicTheFinch @KordingLab @andpru @EricMTrautmann Yes. Exactly. And it really has to be at least a bit lower dimensional that the full space b/c of biophysical constraints (e.g. a connected pair of excitatory & inhibitory neurons cannot simultaneously be firing at a high rate).

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @KordingLab You're getting silly here. I think you are saying that there may be points visited in the space that are not observed in a particular experiments, hence the manifold is undrestimated. Of course. But not all points will be visited, at the very least due to biopysical constraints.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @andpru @EricMTrautmann @KordingLab Agreed, and for sure these visualization methods make assumptions that are falsifiable. E.g., maybe we shouldn't reduce dimensionality because brain is really high d! But these feel different to me from mechanistic explanations such as synergy being the mechanism for binding.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @SandeepKishor13 @KordingLab From paper by @mjaztwit and Arash Afraz:  https://t.co/PWU70Y9OAj

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @EricMTrautmann @KordingLab Yes. It would be like tossing out PCA or the PSTH. Those visualization methods can sometimes send us down the wrong path (and they have!) but they aren't inherently right or wrong; they are methods of visualizing & conceptualizing data.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @KordingLab Yes: remembering that neural activity is restricted to manifolds helps interpret perturbations. The fact that many perturbations are off-manifold makes us think more deeply about them. W/out this framework, folks noted that perturbations were "unnatural" but were vague about why.  https://t.co/ShNzOUcH3i

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @KordingLab I'm pro-skepticism but don't understand the argument here. Binding-by-synergy was wrong so other new ideas must also be wrong? Plus, including manifolds in the list seems weird: they aren't a mechansintic explanation but a description that helps make sense of population activity.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @LennartVerhagen @KordingLab In all cases, note that you have the prerogative as the speaker to request that all non-clarification questions be held off till the discussion. You are the only one with the mic so in the end, you get to determine how the seminar unfolds. Good luck!

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @LennartVerhagen @KordingLab Type 3 is tough to handle. Comments are often non-substantive because the objection isn‚Äôt scientific, it‚Äôs emotional. And personal. Solution: thank them for the comment & ask them to send you some literature. This is respectful & may diffuse the situation.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @LennartVerhagen @KordingLab Type 3: Person is mad b/c their dept members‚Äô enthusiasm for you exceeds what they think you deserve. If your seminar gets moved to a bigger room b/c the original room couldn‚Äôt accommodate the crowd, this person will turn up!

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @LennartVerhagen @KordingLab If Type 2 persists in objecting, tell your host: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd be happy to skip my presentation and instead spend this hour explaining why decision-making is a field. Would you prefer I do that?‚Äù Your host will not.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @LennartVerhagen @KordingLab Type 2: Person objects to your entire field. Solution: Deflect this for a post-talk chat & try to get to the bottom of their objection. This might allow you to develop language for future talks that obviates such concerns.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @LennartVerhagen @KordingLab Type 1: Person has a genuine scientific concern but (sadly) was taught to express concern very aggressively. Solution: Breathe, keep it light & get them to be very specific in their concerns. They probably actually want to learn something.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @LennartVerhagen @KordingLab Here are tips for handling 3 types of difficult interactions you might encounter while giving a seminar. Note that in all cases, the person is likely a known quantity in the department & has heckled folks before. The audience knows this.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @jpillowtime @KordingLab @kendmil @mjaztwit @AkramiLab @litalchart @sashankpisupati @anupkhanal That's close to our model. I think @KordingLab 's model is equivalent to epsilon greedy exploration: subject makes a random choice on x% of trials. But this predicts lapse rate will be the same on all conditions, which it is not. Uncertainty-guided exploration is our alternative.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @KordingLab @jpillowtime @mjaztwit @AkramiLab @litalchart @sashankpisupati @anupkhanal What is rct?

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @jpillowtime @mjaztwit @AkramiLab @litalchart @sashankpisupati @anupkhanal Agree. To put it another way, some easy errors are attentional lapses, some are motor misfires and some are uncertainty guided exploration. This is a fundamentally new way of thinking about lapses that will better explain behavior & guide interpretation of neural data.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @mjaztwit @AkramiLab @litalchart @sashankpisupati @anupkhanal @jpillowtime I am partially thinking along the same lines but am not sure current version of the statistical model can account for asymmetric rewards. @jpillowtime we should discuss.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @mjaztwit @chris_fetsch @valentinwyart @sashankpisupati I agree üíØ & am confident that lapses are driven by multiple factors (shown by @valentinwyart & @pillow). But the starting point of this thread was that our effects may be restricted to rodents. We know this isn't the case b/c we see uncertainty dependent lapse in humans too.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @chris_fetsch @valentinwyart @sashankpisupati @mjaztwit More attention on multisensory trials as an explanation for low lapses is refuted by neutral multisensory trials: one modality is at category boundary so provides no info. We see higher lapses on those neutral trials (that's the 2012 fig I posted earlier & Fig 3 in current paper)

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @LongDingPA @sashankpisupati @chris_fetsch @valentinwyart Nice! Esp Monkey A.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @chris_fetsch @valentinwyart @sashankpisupati The key finding from Raposo et Al is that the lapse rate varies across conditions, even in humans. Traditional explanations for lapse (attention/motor error) don't predict that.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @chris_fetsch @valentinwyart @sashankpisupati I disagree that animals lapse but humans don't. In our humans, rats & mice, lapses decrease w/ experience, but don't usually disappear (esp on unisensory). Note that @valentinwyart aknowledges a 5% lapse rate in humans which is not that low. See mouse below (Odeomene et al 2018).  https://t.co/1W1Gcx3JXo

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @mrhunsaker @sheacshl @sashankpisupati @litalchart Thanks! Also note that the lapses are guided by uncertainty about the stimulus which is a clever strategy.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @bradpwyble @litalchart @sashankpisupati @anupkhanal I agree with you that lapses may be driven by more than a single cause and that some lapses are due to inattention. But that can't be the whole explanation since humans have more lapses on high uncertainty neutral trials despite a matched attentional load.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @bradpwyble @litalchart @sashankpisupati @anupkhanal Ah, but we see the same thing in humans. Our current study was motivated by observing in humans that lapses are higher on unisensory & multisensory neutral trials (tho we lacked a normative explanation at the time).  https://t.co/Drz3UHbGX1

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @valentinwyart @sashankpisupati And can we please stop with the "Of Mice and Men"? I love Steinbeck, but this is seriously played out at this point. Plus, our paper is about rats, not mice, and half our human subjects were female.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @valentinwyart @sashankpisupati Nope. The effects that motivated our current study, higher lapse on unisensory and neutral multisensory trials, were 1st reported by us in humans in 2012, although we lacked a normative explanation at the time.  https://t.co/rDJHJDEM8g

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @bradpwyble @litalchart @sashankpisupati @anupkhanal That's the point. The information is selected similarly in our two conditions, but late in the decision process, the high uncertainty condition drives lapses.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @bradpwyble @litalchart @sashankpisupati @anupkhanal We also ran a telling experiement (fig 3) in which we interleaved trials that had matched attentional load but different uncertainty. Lapses are higher on uncertain trials compared to more certain trials with the same attentional load.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @bradpwyble @litalchart @sashankpisupati @anupkhanal Nope. Inattention models make the wrong prediction for the changes in the psychometric function when reward size or probability is asymmetric. See fig 4.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @synapticlee @sashankpisupati @neuroecology @litalchart @anupkhanal I don't know exactly what that is but YES!

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @nunezanalyzed We replicated the effect with Neuropixels probes (ephys).

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: Ever botched an easy decision? Our cake explains why. Turns out lapses aren't inattention, but reflect a strategic exploration/exploitation trade-off. name: Anne Churchland

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @ScottMacShack The is helpful b/c when evaluating candidates, we tend to overweight interviews even though they have weak predictive power. If you agree in advance what qualifications matter, and can remind yourselves of those later, it can mitigate the tendency to over-rely on the interview.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @ScottMacShack Not sure I follow. Sounds like you are currently using publication record as a factor. Thus you already have internal criteria that you are leveraging to evaluate this. Your colleagues do too. Make those criteria explicit and write them down.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @ScottMacShack 1. Agree on criteria before screening (num papers, grant support, sci area)  2. When you meet to discuss candidates, restate criteria  3. Document strengths/weaknesses of candidates 4. Revisit 1&3 after interviews 5. Before an offer, identify all candidates who are >threshold

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 10/10 Science is full of emotional ups & downs. If you are really depleted/frustrated/sad, let kids retreat to devices while you re-charge. I know your colleagues brag that their kids never use devices. Ignore them & haul out the iPad when you need it.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 9/10 Teen/Tween trick: There is likely a creative 11-year-old nearby who is bored and could be a ‚Äúparents‚Äô helper.‚Äù S/he can play 23 rounds of Uno w/ kids while you finish that paper you started. Bonus: getting to know your neighbors.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 8/10 Domestic slacker trick: Devote minimum time to household tasks. Free time you carve out can be spent on science, not chopping carrots (Buy those pre-cut! I *know* your colleague grows heirloom carrots in the garden. Ignore him/her!)

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 7/10 Timer trick: Set a timer for 20 mins. Put it outside your workspace so kids can easily see it. Tell them to interrupt for emergencies but otherwise to pls wait for the timer. For older kids, provide paper for jotting down their needs so you can help later. Repeat as needed.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 6/10 Plan-ahead trick Part 2: Do high-energy play w/kids. They might be more willing to chill & draw/ look at books if they get the wiggles out at the playground. Pro tip: race around with them to enhance the effect. Bonus: You‚Äôll like it!

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 5/10 Plan-ahead trick Part 1: Play together to create stuff for future independent play: pillow fort, reading tent, lego town. As you go, have them lead the way: ‚ÄúWhich animals live in this fort?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhere should the roads be?‚Äù Then fade away...

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 4/10 Lego trick: Keep searching for toys they love & stock up on those. I got my 1st R01 b/c of Lego. Yep, I indulged my kid & gave a big lego set on a non-birthday. I got my grant, he turned out okay, & we still have that x-wing fighter.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 3/10 Toy exchange trick: Grant deadline coming up? Ask a neighbor to lend you a big box of toys. The novelty of new stuff will keep kids engaged for longer than their own toys. Pro tip: buy neighbor a bottle of wine to sweeten the deal.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 2/10 Hidden toy trick: Your kids probably get lots of stuff- party bags, gifts from nana, garage sale gems. Hide it all! Sequester toys in shoeboxes (or a funnier shaped box) hidden away in a closet. Unearth them when you need to read a paper.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @SussilloDavid @KordingLab Yes, I do agree that failing to account for energy costs could limit relevance to neuroscience computations (which can't be so search-y). But I like the reminder that our intuitions about how to implement computations can be misleading.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @KordingLab @cian_neuro In my view, no. We can & should decode, but we should be open about which computations support behaviors we want to understand. E.g. although edges are a salient part of my visual experience & they drive V1 well, V1 cells are not "edge detectors," they are spatiotemporal filters.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @jmourabarbosa @mariam_s_aly @weijima01 @KordingLab I suggest this because scientists frequently use emotional language that is devoid of content: "This is ridiculous!" "I don't know anyone who thinks this!" or, "Oh, come on...". These are effective ways to win arguments, but not effective for advancing knowledge & understanding.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @jmourabarbosa @mariam_s_aly @weijima01 @KordingLab My tip: Teach trainees/PIs to give very specific feedback. E.g. if reading a paper you don't like, it's not productive to say, "These people are idiots!" Instead: "The paper's premise is flawed because of x,y & z, and the data analysis methods prevent confidence in conclusions."

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @sard1d @tyrell_turing @elasri_layla 0. Indeed! 1. I am missing why you think we know little. Decision-making is a well-established field & I keep linking papers that investigate the ideas we are discussing. 2. We study learning too, both behavior & brain (via 2-photon imaging). See Fig 6.  https://t.co/IueFBX4ZQj

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @sard1d @tyrell_turing @elasri_layla Here, we examined 500,000 mouse decisions. Though mice are well trained, their decisions are shaped by about 6 parameters, the wts of which vary. Even if we could ask mice their strategy, would they list all 6 params & know the weights & their dynamics?  https://t.co/jY6KH16xif

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @sard1d @tyrell_turing @elasri_layla My human subjects come in every day for 20 days. They make 1000 decisions each day. I would not describe that regime as "naive subjects in an unknown task."   https://t.co/dLIWrKlio8

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @sard1d @tyrell_turing @elasri_layla If there is a study in which subjects making serial decisions become consciously aware of bias and mitigate it, pls link!! I have never seen this in my lab. Decisions do slowly improve with training, but subjects can't articulate why.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @sard1d @tyrell_turing @elasri_layla No, we really can't understand, even in retrospect. For instance, decisions can be biased by irrelevant information (e.g., repeating previous decisions when in fact each situation is independent). People are blind to these biases & think they only use current evidence.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @HengartnerMP ADHD symptoms are already known to be more or less visible depending on cognitive load: e.g, symptoms are often more apparent at school where the impulse-control demands are high, and are attenuated at home, where such demands are more relaxed.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @Till_S_Hartmann @AnupamBJena @nytimes article argues that younger kids are misdiagnosed b/c their inattentiveness resembles ADHD. But we can't rule out an alternative explanation: the high rates among Aug b-day kids is b/c challenges they face in class makes their ADHD more visible.  https://t.co/2pa9AQiKdM

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: Finally (3/2?) I do think there is room for improvement in #ADHD diagnosis. But many of the objections are driven by stigma against cognitive dysfunction and bias against treating cognitive/mental irregularities w/ medication. I favor acceptance and openness to treatment options.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 2/2 Authors claim #ADHD diagnosis is subjective b/c kids w/ August b-days are diagnosed more frequently. Not convincing: younger kids face bigger cognitive challenges than older classmates. ADHD, like other cognitive irregularities, is more apparent during such big challenges.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 1/2 In a problematic article, authors claim that since 5% of kids are diagnosed with ADHD, it is overdiagnosed. But the 5% rate is uninformative about overdiagnosis. Some childhood problems occur at high rates: e.g., 20% of kids have vision problems. #ADHD  https://t.co/2pa9AQiKdM

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @iandanforth The mice would make better decisions if they ignored the prior and went with the evidence.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @chris_fetsch Monkeys have trial history effects also.  https://t.co/5d4pV8smM2 This is an example of relying on irrelevant information instead of evidence.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @iandanforth Mice can ignore reliable evidence (e.g. visual cue) and rely on priors (e.g., choose "right-" it was rewarded last time). But previous outcome is irrelevant; trials are generated by a computer and are independent. Humans likewise can ignore reliable evidence and rely on priors.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: Peer review is harmed b/c reviewers can't totally ignore irrelevant information about authors (nationality & gender are highlighted here:  https://t.co/RGm8KuOZCm). My mice also use irrelevant information for decisions so this is a common problem. Let's be better than the mice!!

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @sterrett_sc @simonMusall @MattAntimatt Not quite, because neurons that are not in categories might still be strongly selective. It is just that they are selective for idiosyncratic parameter combinations as opposed to being selective for "color" and not "motion" and thus are in the "color" category.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: A new paper in @JNeurophysiol reports on a new test for neural categories. Please use this test and don't assume categories! It is very general and allows for the fact that some neurons might be in categories and others not.  https://t.co/2vlzU3quVe @UMNeurosci @MattAntimatt

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @tsonj @KordingLab @Neuro_Skeptic @kellyfj1 Oh, thanks for clarifying your point, @tsonj! You might rightly accuse me of "annsplaining."

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @tsonj @KordingLab @Neuro_Skeptic @kellyfj1 There is variance in a signal (e.g. I am tweeting now and you are not) and we want to explain that variance (e.g. I am further west than you and people in the west are tweeting now).

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @Neuro_Skeptic @kellyfj1 Yep, it will be more predictable than one might think. Brains are dynamical systems that explore (sometimes low-d) state spaces. Many of these states can be identified by movement params (e.g. pupil diameter, running speed). Clear in widefield microscopy:  https://t.co/yzYTojNFuc

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @kellyfj1 @Neuro_Skeptic Brains have about 70 billion neurons. But the actual dimensionality is waaaaay lower. So you don't need to predict the activity of each neuron.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @danbri @SussilloDavid Supporting metadata: a huge issue! Right now much metadata is lost so datasets have limited usefulness. Basic parameters like mouse genetic background are not linked to data. Solutions:  https://t.co/FOeNMl23cz Colony management software. @HHMIJanelia has one too. @svoboda314

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @danbri @SussilloDavid Data sharing: Some organizations committed, eg @AllenInstitute @IntlBrainLab & some individual labs too. But not widespread in part b/c the infrastructure to make it feasible is not in place. E.g., who pays to host the data? Who helps the trainee get it into a good format?

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @SussilloDavid I could not agree more! Data and analysis pipelines are an additional issue that will need much consideration. Most of us are not where we should be wrt data architecture.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @HibitJustin @sheacshl @simonMusall @MattAntimatt We find that movement activity dwarfs sensory/cognitive activity cortex-wide. Easy to distinguish from sensory/cognitive signals

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @WiringTheBrain @neuroecology @simonMusall @MattAntimatt The surprise was that movement related signals (1) dwarf decision-making signals and (2) resemble decision-making signals. This last point is important: had we not compared novice & expert subjects, we would have misinterpreted many of the signals as being decision-related.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @m4loman @shadlen @KordingLab @CarolineDeanLab You can start here:  https://t.co/2jssIdagez  Paper uses symbolic regression which is inappropriate for neural data model discovery but you'll get the idea. @KordingLab: true about many models but one can go way beyond comparing two instantiations of a class of models & doing BIC

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @shadlen @KordingLab @CarolineDeanLab The point of model discovery is that you explore the entire space of possible models, including the ‚Äúdark spaces‚Äù, as opposed to a finite set of a priori chosen models. It might be the opposite of hubris.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @shadlen @KordingLab @CarolineDeanLab @shadlen I am surprised you are unenthusiastic about model discovery. It is an antidote to the ad hoc model comparison approach that can lead to particular parameterizations winning the day unfairly.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @kaymtye @patchurchland @UCSDNeuro Oh, great photo!!! She said your talk was really good! I think you have selfies with all Churchlands now, @kaymtye #sciencemums

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @KordingLab @shadlen @CarolineDeanLab There are new "model discovery" methods that search for the right model rather than making ad hoc comparisons of specific model instantiations (which may indeed be unfair). Tatiana Engel and I plan to collaborate to do this.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @shadlen @CarolineDeanLab In the neuro we both know, great care is needed to interpret signals that reflect averages over trials, neurons etc. That the same challenges are present in the very different field of plant biology is notable.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: At talk from @CarolineDeanLab, I learned that plants integrate light & temp w/ internal signals about stress to decide flowering. Also, root cells that undergo a step change at single cell level that resembles a ramp when averaged. Holy smokes, neuro & plant folks should team up!

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @scicurious @bpisaacoff @ElyseTheGeek @scicurious I agree; this is why I advocate rephrasing the question to allow people a wider variety of responses, and to leave it up to them whether they wished to discuss sexism or now. I don't think the current phrasing is ideal for men or women.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @scicurious @bpisaacoff @ElyseTheGeek Is it the case that asking people whether they have experienced priviledge helps them to recognize it? I don't know the data on this.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @scicurious I didn't choose those words b/c they were nicer. I chose them b/c (1) they give women the chance to highlight sexism if they wish to (2) they don't put women on the spot if they don't wish to (3) they open a door for challenges beyond sexism: e.g. depression, health, finances...

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @scicurious Perhaps there is a more general question, suitable for all:   What challenges have you faced during your career & what have you learned that might be useful to others?  It's better because it's more inclusive & doesn't force folks to discuss sexism/racism if they prefer not to.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @scicurious I'm okay w/ the question. It gives me a chance to remind people that w/in science we have not yet achieved a level playing field for who is hired, funded, and promoted. By leveling the playing field, we will be better able to nurture talented scientists of all genders, races, etc

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: @rei_akaishi Strategy is idiosyncratic: monkeys in the Yates paper and mice in our & @brody_lab paper weight early evidence more. Rats & humans in our paper and rats in previous @Brodylab papers weights evidence evenly. So mouse=monkey; rat=human.

name: Anne Churchland
tweet: 2 @biorxiv papers (1 ours) tackle evidence accumulation in mice  https://t.co/4snLzovQza  https://t.co/Wl0JPCd85A Nice work, @brody_lab! Cool: both report early weighting in mouse decisions. Odd: mice are like monkeys & rats are like humans. @IlanaWitten @lucasmpinto @kachiodemz
